data.title: 25,000 AT FIRST PORT WAKEFIELD SPEED MEETING
data.meta_description: A crowd of about 25,000 surrounded the new bitumen racing track near Port Wakefield yesterday, when Brooklyn Park Speedway S.A., Ltd., conducted its first car and motor cycle speed meeting. Crack racing car drivers thrilled the huge concourse with bursts ...
data.text:
There was another thrill when

a car driven by G. W. Patterson,

of Victoria, which was leading the

field at terrific speed in a lap o£

the Group Handicap (Group 1),

failed to enter the western S bend

and shot down an escape road.

There were seven races for

cars, ranging from 13. to 26 miles,

and seven for motor' cycles from

11 to 21 miles. Hie programme

opened at 11 a.m. and was not

concluded until 5.30 p.m.—about

an hour behind schedule. Laps

were over 1.3 miles, with an S

bend at the eastern end and a

liairpen bend at the western end.

Cars were in lines of three fill

ing two roads leading to the

course. Shortly before the opening

cars were stretched out for about

a mile. A big squad of police on

duty was praised by speedway of

ficials for the manner in which

the traffic was handled. There

were only brief pauses as the

lines were merged into one at

'each entrance track. A ' breeze

from the sea made for pleasant

conditions and reduced dust, an

noyance when racing, curs left the

bitumen track. !

In declaring the speedway open !

Mr. C. S. Hincks (Minister of

Lands" congratulated the promo

ters on their enterprise. He said

that Mr. T. C. Burford. a one

time racing motor cyclist, had

taken a prominent part in pre

liminary arrangements for. forma

tion of the track following (he

Parliamentary ban on road rac

ing.

Following the ceremony, Mi'.

Hincks was driven round the

course in the official car.

FAVORABLE COMMENT

Drivers spoke favorably of the

new track; but some suggested

that attention - should be given to

more extensive grading at the

sides for the benefit of vehicles

which left the bitumen.

Les March, a prominent driver

in hill climbs, and Bill Craig,

another promising driver, were in

jured in separate crashes while

engaged in practise runs on Wed

nesday. Both received treatment

at Balaklava Hospital, being al

lowed to leave afterward.

Driving a Morgan Plus 4, P.

McK.' Hay had a meritorious win

in the Class C Gi'oup Scratch race

for cars over 13 miles (10 laps).

One of the State's up and coming

drivers, he took the lead early,

withstanding a strong challenge

by R. S. Brown (MGTC).

The crowd was on its toes when

Hay roared into the northern

straight in the third lap where a

car which had been lapped had

broken down. Frantic efforts of

officials just managed to get the

disabled vehicle clear before Hay

bore down.

Soon after the start of the

class B Group Scratch race a

Jowett Javelin Special, driven by

A. J. Wylie (Victoria), left the

bitumen in a cloud of dust, but

was driven back skilfully into the

race. P. Harrison -{Victoria'),

driving a Dodge Special, had an

all the way win. .

Six drivers entered for the

Class A Group Scratch Race over

13 miles (10 laps). A. N. ("Lex")

Davison, at the wheel of his Alfa

Romeo, took the lead, followed

closely by S. J. Jones, another

Victorian, driving a Maybach, re

puted to he the fastest car in

Australia.

DASHING DUEL

The crowd was thrilled at a

clashing dueMjetween the two ace

-drivers, and when Jones went to

the front in the eighth lap ex

citement was intense. Zooming

along the northern straight in the

next, lap Davison was in hot pur- ;

suit- when his rear tyre blew out i

when he was entering the S bend.

The Alfa Romeo careered off

the bitumen toward the inside of

the track, overturning several

times and coming to rest upside

down, Davison being thrown clear j

several yards away.

The race went to Jones, with E.

DeB. Norman (Maserati 6C) the

only other driver to be placed.

An average lap speed of 68 miles

an hour (fastest of the day) was

noted in this event.

Later in the day it was reported

thai. Davison's injuries were not

of a serious nature. He and Jones

had been booked to leave shortly

for the famous Monte Carlo

Rally.

Feature of the 26-mile Group

Handicap (Group 1) event was

the magnificent driving of Jones,

who came from the scratch mark

to overtake the field, giving him

his second success.

Heavy entries were noted in the i

motor cycle events, the Port

Wakefield Senior T.T. going to

M. Quincey (Victoria). The side-!

car T.T. was won by L. W. Fox.

RESULTS

Results of the various events

were as follows:—
